content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Compare the prices for round-trip flights from New York to Tokyo for a departure on May 10, 2026, and a return on May 24, 2026, and select the option with the least number of stops.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To begin searching for flights from New York to Tokyo, I need to enter "New York" as the departure city, replacing "Toronto" in the "Where from?" field.
Action: Type [13]; New York
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure city is set to "New York." Next, I need to enter "Tokyo" as the destination city in the "Where to?" field to proceed with the flight search.
Action: Type [14]; Tokyo
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure and destination fields are now correctly set to "New York" and "Tokyo." The next step is to enter the departure date (May 10, 2026) in the "Departure" date field.
Action: Type [16]; May 10, 2026
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date "Sun, May 10, 2026" is already selected (highlighted on the calendar). Next, I need to select the return date "Sun, May 24, 2026" from the calendar.
Action: Click [39]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The return date "Sun, May 24, 2026" is now selected. Both departure and return dates are set correctly. The next step is to confirm these dates by clicking the "Done" button to proceed to flight search results.
Action: Click [79]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The flight search parameters (round trip, New York, Tokyo, departure and return dates) are set. The next step is to initiate the flight search by clicking the "Search" button to view available flights.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar view with selected dates is being shown again, likely as a step to confirm, but the selected dates remain correct (May 10 to May 24). To proceed to the actual flight options (where number of stops can be compared), it is necessary to click "Done."
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The previous step has returned to the main flight search page, but the dates and routes should still be set correctly. To ensure that search results showing flights are loaded, I need to click the "Search" button again.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The interface has returned to the calendar price selection, indicating the dates and route need to be confirmed. Clicking "Done" should finalize the dates and allow access to search results where I can analyze the number of stops.
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page has returned again to the main flight search screen, likely after date confirmation. The fields should have been set; now clicking "Search" is necessary to generate the list of specific flight options where stops and prices can be compared.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page has reverted again to the calendar/price selection interface. The dates May 10, 2026 (departure) and May 24, 2026 (return) are visible, with prices for those dates shown as $1,360. I need to confirm these dates by clicking "Done" so I can proceed to the flight options page to compare the number of stops.
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.92
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have finalized the travel dates and returned to the main search page with all details filled out (New York to Tokyo, May 10 to May 24, 2026). It is necessary to click the "Search" button again to view the actual list of flight options so I can compare the number of stops.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.95
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The interface has again reverted to the calendar for selecting dates, with May 10 and May 24 highlighted and minimum price visible. To proceed and see flight options (and number of stops), I must click "Done."
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.97
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The previous "Done" click returned to the main flight search screen. The travel details are all set, so I need to click "Search" again to load the actual flight results for comparing stop numbers and selecting the best option.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.98
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screen is showing the calendar view again with the correct dates (May 10 and May 24, 2026) selected and the lowest visible price. To move forward to the step where I can actually compare flight options (number of stops), I must click "Done."
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.99
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The selection has reverted to the main search page with all fields filled. The travel details are set (New York to Tokyo, May 10 to May 24, 2026), so I need to click the "Search" button to view available flights and compare the number of stops.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screenshot shows that we've returned to the date selection calendar with May 10 and May 24, 2026, in focus. To proceed further and finally get to the flight comparison page (to see the number of stops), I need to click "Done."
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[2]: <button> "Travel";	[3]: <button> "Explore";	[4]: <button> "Flights";	[5]: <button> "Hotels";	[6]: <button> "Vacation rentals";	[7]: <button> "Change appearance";	[9]: "Sign in";	[11]: <button> "1", "1 passenger";	[13]: <input> "Where from?";	[14]: <button> "Swap origin and destination.";	[15]: <input> "Where to?";	[16]: <input> "Departure";	[17]: <button> "";	[18]: <button> "";	[19]: <input> "Return";	[20]: <button> "Search";	[21]: <button> "Explore deals";

Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0

Thought: The screenshot still shows the calendar date selection. Both May 10 and May 24, 2026, are visible as travel dates, but the flight search results with stop details are not yet shown. To proceed and view those results, I must click the "Done" button.
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
